TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicant was born in DATE and lives in GPE .
CARDINAL . In DATE he decided to move from GPE to GPE . He negotiated a real estate deal with a GPE - based agent .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant withdrew from his bank accounts MONEY ( “ USD ” ) in cash and asked his acquaintance , B. , to deliver the money to GPE .
CARDINAL . B. arrived in the Sheremetyevo-CARDINAL airport DATE . He failed to declare the money at the customs checkpoint and was charged with smuggling .

CARDINAL . On DATE , ORG of GPE found B. guilty of smuggling under LAW and sentenced him to DATE suspended imprisonment . With regard to the money , the court said in the operative part of the judgment :
“ USD MONEY , deposited with ORG , are to be forfeited to the ORG as an object of smuggling . ”

CARDINAL . In his appeal against the judgment , PERSON 's lawyer submitted that ORG had failed to indicate any legal ground for the conﬁscation order . He argued that the money had been included in the case - ﬁle as evidence and that no relevant law provided for its conﬁscation . Moreover , lawfully obtained assets were to be returned to their owners . PERSON 's lawyer also claimed that LAW did not provide for such a sanction as conﬁscation .
CARDINAL . On DATE , ORG refused the appeal . With regard to the money , the court said :
“ USD MONEY , which was the object of the smuggling , was rightfully forfeited to the ORG . ”

CARDINAL . On DATE a Deputy President of ORG lodged an application for supervisory review against the judgments . He claimed that the smuggled money could only be conﬁscated if proven to have been acquired criminally .

CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG of ORG refused the application on the ground that a Ruling of the Plenary Supreme Court of the GPE issued in DATE permitted the conﬁscation of smuggled goods which had been attached to case - ﬁles as exhibits .

CARDINAL . On DATE the Deputy President of ORG lodged another application for supervisory review claiming , among other things , that DATE was inconsistent with later superseding legislation . However , on an unspeciﬁed date the Deputy President of ORG withdrew his application .
CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL of LAW of DATE , as in force from DATE to DATE , provided :

“ The carrying across the [ State ] border of considerable amounts of goods or other items ... in evasion of customs controls ... or without declaring [ them ] or with untrue declarations ... shall be penalised by imprisonment of up to ﬁve DATE ... and by forfeiture of the goods and other items carried across the border ... ”
CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL of LAW of DATE ( “ CrC ” ) provides :

“ Smuggling , i.e. transportation across the customs border of GPE of considerable amounts of goods and other items ... without due customs control , or in evasion of such control , or with fraudulent use of documents or identiﬁcation means , or in violation of rules of declaration , shall be penalised by imprisonment of up to ﬁve DATE . ”
CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL of LAW , as in force at the material time , provided :

“ Failure to declare or an inadequate declaration of goods ... carried across the customs border ... which disclose no appearance of smuggling ... shall be punished by a ﬁne of MONEY of the cost of the goods which are the object of the offence , with or without their forfeiture ... ”
CARDINAL . The Code of Criminal Procedure of DATE ( “ CCrP ” ) , in force at the relevant time , provided as follows :

“ Exhibits include items which served as instruments of crime , or which have retained traces of the crime , or against which the crime was directed . [ Exhibits also include ] criminally acquired money and other valuables earned by crime , and any other items which can help detect the crime , establish factual circumstances , reveal the guilty or refute the charges or lessen the responsibility . ”
“ The destiny of exhibits used in criminal proceedings must be determined in a judgment ... , and :
CARDINAL . instruments of the crime which belong to the accused shall be conﬁscated and passed to a competent agency or destroyed ;
CARDINAL . NORP items prohibited for circulation shall be passed to a competent agency or destroyed ;
CARDINAL . items of no value or use shall be destroyed or returned to interested persons or agencies if they so wish ;

CARDINAL . NORP criminally acquired money and other assets shall be forfeited ; other items shall be returned to their lawful owners , or , if the owners are not established , shall become the ORG 's property . In the event of a dispute concerning the ownership of such items , the dispute shall be resolved in civil proceedings ;
CARDINAL . documents which serve as exhibits shall be kept in the case ﬁle as long as the case ﬁle is archived or shall be passed to interested agencies ” .
CARDINAL . The Ruling of the Plenary Supreme Court of the GPE no . CARDINAL of DATE ( “ the Ruling of the Supreme Court ” , “ the Ruling ” ) provides :
“ ... With a view to ensure a uniform and correct application of laws in proceedings concerning smuggling , ORG decides [ that ] : ...
CARDINAL . NORP In accordance with the legislation in force , smuggled items must be forfeited as exhibits ... ”
CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL - CARDINAL of LAW of DATE ( “ CivC ” ) provides :
“ In cases established by law , a person may be deprived of his property without compensation pursuant to a court judgment as a sanction for a crime or other offence ( conﬁscation ) ... ”

CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG of ORG exercised supervisory review of the criminal case against a certain Mr PERSON , who had been convicted of smuggling a considerable amount of foreign currency into GPE . After conviction , the trial court returned the money DATE which had been included in the ﬁle as evidence – to its owner , PERSON . ORG overturned the judgment having found that the money should have been considered as an instrument of the crime and , as such , it should have been conﬁscated pursuant to LAW

CARDINAL . On DATE , ORG held that LAW was constitutional , even though it permitted to conﬁscate instruments of crime , for example smuggled money , belonging to other than the accused . In particular , ORG said :

“ The rule set out in ... LAW ... helps GPE implement its international - law obligations in criminal proceedings , does not overrule criminal laws which permit conﬁscation as a punishment , and , hence , allows the procedural law to regulate conﬁscation with regard to [ international instruments on money laundering and crime control ] .
It is a [ criminal ] court ... who may determine the procedural status of [ smuggled items ] under LAW .... ”
